Dear Ms. Brewer:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 243-9743.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
Description service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth are taken to the hospital and proper information is not
available and provided.
Investigation The Chief Administrator was interviewed on 02/20/2024 during
an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated she
had not personally accompanied any youth to the hospital at that
time because she was still transitioning from a Social Service
Worker position to the Chief Administrator position. The Chief
Administrator did state there was a procedure within the program
for staff to take a youth’s log book with them when they are
transported or accompany a youth to the hospital.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 02/29/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She reviewed the procedure that
was provided to Licensing from the Chief Administrator and stated
she could not recall seeing that specific document or specific
instruction. Staff 1 stated she was familiar with the practice of
taking medical insurance, health history and legal status
information to medical providers when accompanying youth. Staff
1 believed she was taught to do this by the previous Chief
Administrator. Staff 1 stated she had been with youth at the local
hospital on several occasions and never failed to have proper
information that the hospital or mental health staff would need to
provide services to the youth.
Youth A was interviewed on 02/29/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated she has had to go to
the hospital a few times during her placement at the facility for
medications and during times of crisis. Youth A could not recall
who accompanied her to the hospital, but she believed staff had
her “case file” with them to provide information to staff there.
2

Youth B was interviewed on 02/29/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth B believed staff brought
necessary information with them to visits to the hospital and
medical providers but could not recall any specific details on those
instances.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed on 02/29/2024 during an
unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated she was
trained since the beginning of her employment to take “the book”
with her if she accompanied a youth to the hospital or a medical
appointment, and she believed she had done that “most of the
time.” Supervisor 1 stated that essential information such as legal
status and insurance was always contained in this book. She
stated she recently learned about the card that is provided for
each youth placed in the program that outlines consent to treat for
youth in the child welfare system.
Staff 3 was interviewed on 03/07/2024 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. Staff 3 stated she has taken
several youth to medical appointments and to the hospital for
medication refills and for crisis needs and she has never
accompanied the youth without their “book” to provide medical
and legal information to the service provider. When asked
specifically about an instance in November 2023 where she
transported a youth to the hospital, Staff 3 stated she could not
recall the specific date, but she would not have transported the
youth without the required information. She stated she had seen
the specific document that was provided to Licensing that outlined
the facility procedures for this activity. Staff 3 stated there have
been times of confusion during these visits because youth in the
program often refer to her as “Grandma”, and she believed this
was done in part due to embarrassment of the youth and not
wanting it known where they are placed. Staff 3 stated she has
tried to correct this to avoid confusion but did not want to
embarrass the youth, either.
Youth C was interviewed on 03/13/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated she had been
transported to the hospital on one occasion during her time placed
at the facility, but this was done by law enforcement. Youth C
could not recall if staff that met her there brought proper
information for the service providers.
Youth D was interviewed over the phone on 03/15/2024. She
stated that there were several times she had to be taken to the
hospital during her previous time placed at the program. Youth D
3

recalled that the Licensee Designee took her more than once and
believed other staff had as well. Youth D believed there were
times when she was at the hospital for services provided by local
Community Mental Health’s Crisis team and there was not proper
information provided by facility staff to the service
providers. Youth D could not provide any further detail on what
she recalled.
The Licensee Designee was interviewed over the phone on
03/15/2024. She stated there had been several occasions where
she accompanied youth to medical appointments or to the local
hospital for crisis services or needs for medication
management. The Licensee Designee stated she could not
specifically recall any dates where there had been concern
presented on proper information not being brought in for the
needs of the service providers at the hospital, including the
specific date in January 2024 regarding a hospital visit with Youth
D. She recalled the normal practice to be calling the caseworker
for a youth during business hours or calling the on-call line for that
youth’s local home county when there was a need to take the
youth to the hospital.
Documents reviewed:
• Administration staff from Saginaw County Community
Mental Health (CMH) provided documentation as follows:
o Two specific examples of instances where youth
were brought to the local hospital and CMH staff
provided crisis-oriented services to the youth were
provided:
▪ It was summarized that a previously placed
youth in the program was brought to the
emergency room by Staff 3 on
11/05/2023. This was within an hour of CMH
staff taking a phone call from facility staff
inquiring about an urgent need to fill
prescription medications for this youth
through the emergency room and crisis
services. CMH staff reported Staff 3 did not
have any information on consents or legal
status of the youth to provide to them when
they were present at the hospital. At that
point CMH staff made efforts to contact the
youth’s caseworker to gain the required
information. This youth was then brought to
the hospital again for medication needs on
11/13/2023 and 11/14/2023 without proper
4

information on medication history, consents
and legal status. CMH reported they worked
with the facility and gained that information for
this youth as of 11/16/2023.
▪ It was summarized that Youth D was
transported to the local hospital emergency
room by the Licensee Designee on
01/15/2024. CMH staff reported the Licensee
Designee did not have any information
available at this time to inform of consent to
treat or legal status. CMH staff then made
phone calls to on-call staff (due to the federal
holiday) from the youth’s local county to gain
that information.
o A checklist provided to child caring institution staff
and administration by CMH on 02/23/2024 titled
“DHHS Foster Care and CCI Requirements” that
outlined the required documentation that would be
needed for the provision of their services.
▪ A supporting document was provided which
provided more detail specific to crisis needs
titled “List of Required Documents when
Presenting Youth to CIS/Emergency Room.”
• Facility policy & procedure titled “Hospital Instructions” was
provided and reviewed. In this policy it outlined that staff
were required to take the youth’s record book with them to
accompany the youth and were to ensure that the consent
to treat card and face sheet containing demographic
information was included.
o This policy & procedure did not have a date included
on it and was not included in the previously provided
full document of all policy and procedures through
the original Licensure process. The Chief
Administrator and Licensee Designee could not
confirm when it was created or how it was distributed
to staff for their instruction. It was noted that the
document was provided to Licensing on 02/26/2024
and within it has a created date of 02/24/2024.
Analysis Through interviews with youth and staff and documentation
provided by both the facility and the local mental health provider
reviewed there was evidence found the facility did not follow their
own policies on providing required information at the time of need
for service with crisis mental health services.
Conclusion Violation Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Based on the findings in this report a CAP is required.
Per SIR #2024C0001037SI, a 1st provisional license is recommended.
